001// Copyright (c) FIRST and other WPILib contributors.
002// Open Source Software; you can modify and/or share it under the terms of
003// the WPILib BSD license file in the root directory of this project.
004
005package edu.wpi.first.wpilibj;
006
007import edu.wpi.first.util.sendable.Sendable;
008import edu.wpi.first.util.sendable.SendableBuilder;
009import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.smartdashboard.SmartDashboard;
010import java.util.Collection;
011import java.util.HashMap;
012import java.util.HashSet;
013import java.util.Map;
014
015/**
016 * Persistent alert to be sent via NetworkTables. Alerts are tagged with a type of {@code kError},
017 * {@code kWarning}, or {@code kInfo} to denote urgency. See {@link
018 * edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Alert.AlertType AlertType} for suggested usage of each type. Alerts can be
019 * displayed on supported dashboards, and are shown in a priority order based on type and recency of
020 * activation.
021 *
022 * <p>Alerts should be created once and stored persistently, then updated to "active" or "inactive"
023 * as necessary. {@link #set(boolean)} can be safely called periodically.
024 *
025 * <p><b>This API is new for 2025, but is likely to change in future seasons to facilitate deeper
026 * integration with the robot control system.</b>
027 *
028 * <pre>
029 * class Robot {
030 *   Alert alert = new Alert("Something went wrong", AlertType.kWarning);
031 *
032 *   periodic() {
033 *     alert.set(...);
034 *   }
035 * }
036 * </pre>
037 *
038 * <p>Alternatively, alerts which are only used once at startup can be created and activated inline.
039 *
040 * <pre>
041 * public Robot() {
042 *   new Alert("Failed to load auto paths", AlertType.kError).set(true);
043 * }
044 * </pre>
045 */
046public class Alert {
047  private static Map<String, SendableAlerts> groups = new HashMap<String, SendableAlerts>();
048
049  private final AlertType m_type;
050  private boolean m_active;
051  private double m_activeStartTime;
052  private String m_text;
053
054  /**
055   * Creates a new alert in the default group - "Alerts". If this is the first to be instantiated,
056   * the appropriate entries will be added to NetworkTables.
057   *
058   * @param text Text to be displayed when the alert is active.
059   * @param type Alert urgency level.
060   */
061  public Alert(String text, AlertType type) {
062    this("Alerts", text, type);
063  }
064
065  /**
066   * Creates a new alert. If this is the first to be instantiated in its group, the appropriate
067   * entries will be added to NetworkTables.
068   *
069   * @param group Group identifier, used as the entry name in NetworkTables.
070   * @param text Text to be displayed when the alert is active.
071   * @param type Alert urgency level.
072   */
073  @SuppressWarnings("this-escape")
074  public Alert(String group, String text, AlertType type) {
075    if (!groups.containsKey(group)) {
076      groups.put(group, new SendableAlerts());
077      SmartDashboard.putData(group, groups.get(group));
078    }
079
080    m_text = text;
081    m_type = type;
082    groups.get(group).m_alerts.add(this);
083  }
084
085  /**
086   * Sets whether the alert should currently be displayed. This method can be safely called
087   * periodically.
088   *
089   * @param active Whether to display the alert.
090   */
091  public void set(boolean active) {
092    if (active && !m_active) {
093      m_activeStartTime = Timer.getFPGATimestamp();
094    }
095    m_active = active;
096  }
097
098  /**
099   * Updates current alert text. Use this method to dynamically change the displayed alert, such as
100   * including more details about the detected problem.
101   *
102   * @param text Text to be displayed when the alert is active.
103   */
104  public void setText(String text) {
105    m_text = text;
106  }
107
108  private static final class SendableAlerts implements Sendable {
109    private final Collection<Alert> m_alerts = new HashSet<>();
110
111    private String[] getStrings(AlertType type) {
112      return m_alerts.stream()
113          .filter((Alert a) -> a.m_active && a.m_type == type)
114          .sorted((Alert a, Alert b) -> Double.compare(b.m_activeStartTime, a.m_activeStartTime))
115          .map((Alert a) -> a.m_text)
116          .toArray(String[]::new);
117    }
118
119    @Override
120    public void initSendable(SendableBuilder builder) {
121      builder.setSmartDashboardType("Alerts");
122      builder.addStringArrayProperty("errors", () -> getStrings(AlertType.kError), null);
123      builder.addStringArrayProperty("warnings", () -> getStrings(AlertType.kWarning), null);
124      builder.addStringArrayProperty("infos", () -> getStrings(AlertType.kInfo), null);
125    }
126  }
127
128  /** Represents an alert's level of urgency. */
129  public enum AlertType {
130    /**
131     * High priority alert - displayed first on the dashboard with a red "X" symbol. Use this type
132     * for problems which will seriously affect the robot's functionality and thus require immediate
133     * attention.
134     */
135    kError,
136
137    /**
138     * Medium priority alert - displayed second on the dashboard with a yellow "!" symbol. Use this
139     * type for problems which could affect the robot's functionality but do not necessarily require
140     * immediate attention.
141     */
142    kWarning,
143
144    /**
145     * Low priority alert - displayed last on the dashboard with a green "i" symbol. Use this type
146     * for problems which are unlikely to affect the robot's functionality, or any other alerts
147     * which do not fall under the other categories.
148     */
149    kInfo
150  }
151}
